Instrument_Host.name: Hayabusa
Instrument_Host.description: The Hayabusa spacecraft has a box-shaped main body measuring 1.5 m per side and 1.05 m high, with a launch mass of 530 kg, which includes 50 kg of chemical propellant and 65 kg of xenon gas. It features two solar panel wings totaling 12 square meters and a 1.5 m diameter high-gain parabolic antenna. A cylindrical sampler horn and the Minerva lander are mounted on the bottom. The spacecraft uses two microwave ion thrusters for propulsion during cruise phases, providing a peak thrust of 20 mN with 1 kW power, and a nitrogen tetroxide/hydrazine system for maneuvering with 22 N peak thrust. It is powered by gallium-arsenide solar cells and a nickel-metal hydride battery. Communication is conducted via X- and S-band antennas. Hayabusa is equipped with various scientific instruments, including a camera, LIDAR, and spectrometers. The re-entry capsule, 40 cm in diameter, is insulated and protected by a heat shield for high-velocity re-entries. The mission cost approximately 12 billion yen ($100 million U.S.).
